newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila sees 1.9 mln tonnes raw sugar output.
newsitem.headline: Manila sees 1.9 mln tonnes raw sugar output.

text.p: Philippine raw sugar output is expected to increase to 1.9 million tonnes for crop year 1996/1997 (Sept/Aug) from the earlier forecast of 1.76 million, Agriculture Secretary Salvador Escudero said on Friday.
Escudero said at a news conference the higher sugar production forecast for the current crop year was due to "favourable weather conditions."

The Philippine Sugar Board, chaired by Escudero, also approved the importation of 27,000 tonnes of sugar to compensate for the volume of additional exports to the United States for the current crop year, officials said.

"There is nothing wrong in a situation where the government is importing sugar and at the same time exporting sugar to the United States, considering that the American market plays a premium price for Philippine sugar," Escudero said at a news conference.
He said at least seven countries exporting their home-grown sugar to the U.S. market also import cheaper sugar in the world market.
The sugar board announced on Friday it reversed its earlier decision not to take up the additional 27,000 tonnes of sugar export quota to the United States.
Sugar Regulation Administration chief Wilson Gamboa said the board approved to fill up the additional quota due to prospects of a better-than-expected harvest this year.
The additional quota was given on May 12, a U.S. Department of Agriculture official told Reuters. It brings to 273,991 tonnes the total quota given by the United States to the Philippines.
Under the quota system, the U.S. buys sugar from selected countries at a premium over world sugar prices.
